{{unreferenced|date=April 2008}}
'''Selective dissemination of information''' ("SDI") was originally a phrase related to library and information science. SDI refers to tools and resources used to keep a user informed of new resources on specified topics.
SDI services pre-date the [[world wide web]], and the term itself is somewhat dated. Contemporary analogous systems for SDI services include alerts, current awareness tools or trackers. These systems provide automated searches that inform the user of the availability of new resources meeting the user's specified keywords and search parameters. Alerts can be received a number of ways, including [[email]], RSS feeds, [[voice mail]], Instant messaging, and [[text messaging]].
Selective dissemination of information was a concept first described by [[Hans Peter Luhn]] of IBM in the 1950s. Software was developed in many companies and in government to provide this service in the 1950s and 60s, which allowed distribution of items recently published in abstract journals to be routed to individuals who are likely to be interested in the contents. For example, the system at Ft. Monmouth automatically sent out (by mail) a different set of abstracts to each of about 1,000 scientists and engineers in the army depending on what they were working on. The selection was based on an "interest profile," a list of keywords that described their interests. In some organizations, the 'interest profile' was much more than a simple list of keywords. Librarians or information professionals conducted extensive interviews with their clients to establish a fairly complex profile for each individual. Based on these profiles, the information professionals would then distribute selectively appropriate information to their clients. This labour-intensive operation, while initially costly, over time was made less so. A survey at the time (1970s) indicated that a large number of projects were affected by the SDI service. The software was developed by Edward Housman at the Signal Corps Research Laboratories Technical Information Division.
==References==
Hensley, C. B. 1963. Selective Dissemination of Information (SDI): state of the art in May, 1963. ''AFIPS '63, Proceedings of the May 21-23, 1963 Spring Joint Computer Conference'': 257-262. Accessed December 11, 2012, DOI: [https://dx.doi.org/10.1145/1461551.1461584 10.1145/1461551.1461584]
Connor, J. H. 1967. Selective Dissemination of Information - review of literature and issues. ''The Library Quarterly'' 37 (4): 373-391. Accessed December 11, 2015, URL: [https://www.jstor.org/stable/4305823 https://www.jstor.org/stable/4305823].

[[File:B&L Spectronic 20 Colorimeter Cat no33-29-40 tp verso.tif|thumb|right|Using the Bausch & Lomb Spectronic 20 Colorimeter, 1962]]
The '''Spectronic 20''' is a [[brand]] of single-beam [[spectrophotometer]], designed to operate in the [[visible spectrum]]<ref name=Skoog>{{cite book|last1=Skoog|first1=Douglas A.|last2=West|first2=Donald M.|last3=Holler|first3=F. James|last4=Crouch|first4=Stanley R.|title=Fundamentals of analytical chemistry|date=2014|publisher=Brooks Cole|isbn=978-0495558286|page=710|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8bIWAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA710|accessdate=11 November 2015}}</ref> across a wavelength range of 340 [[Nanometer|nm]] to 950 nm, with a [[Spectral linewidth|spectral bandpass]] of 20 nm.<ref name=Murphy>{{cite web|last1=Murphy|first1=Dr. Catherine J.|title=1 Chem 142 LABORATORY MANUAL|url=http://www.chem.sc.edu/faculty/murphy/chem142labmanualspring_09.pdf|website=Department of Chemistry & Biochemistry|publisher=University of South Carolina|accessdate=11 November 2015|quote="The Bausch & Lomb Spectronic 20 spectrophotometer … operates in a wavelength range of 340 to 650 nm. The range may be extended to 950 nm by adding a red filter and changing the phototube detector."}}</ref><ref name=Thermo2007>{{cite book|title=SPECTRONIC 20 + and SPECTRONIC 20D + User Guide|date=2007|publisher=Thermo Fisher Scientific|page=1|url=http://fg.cns.utexas.edu/fg/course_notebook_appendix_ii_files/Spectronic_20_D.pdf}}</ref> It is designed for [[Quantitative analysis (chemistry)|quantitative]] absorption measurement at single wavelengths.<ref name="Skoog" /> Because it measures the [[transmittance]] or [[Absorption (electromagnetic radiation)|absorption]] of visible light through a [[solution]],<ref name=BioLab>{{cite web|title=The Spectrophotometer|url=http://www.explorebiology.com/documents/Lab17Spectrophotometer2005.pdf|website=AP Biology Lab}}</ref> it is sometimes referred to as a [[Colorimeter (chemistry)|colorimeter]].<ref name=Buie/><ref name="Jarnutowski">{{cite journal|last1=Jarnutowski|first1=R.|last2=Ferraro|first2=J. R.|last3=Lankin|first3=D. C.|title=Fifty years of commercial instrumentation in absorption spectroscopy, part II. Landmark instruments in UV/vis|journal=Spectroscopy|date=1992|volume=7|pages=22–24, 26}}</ref> The name of the instrument is a [[trademark]] of the manufacturer.<ref name="Thermo2007" />
Developed by [[Bausch & Lomb]] and launched in 1953, the Spectronic 20 was the first low-cost [[Ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy|UV-Vis spectrophotometer]].<ref name=Buie>{{cite web|last1=Buie|first1=John|title=Evolution of UV-Vis Spectrophotometers|url=http://www.labmanager.com/lab-product/2011/07/evolution-of-uv-vis-spectrophotometers|website=Lab Manager|date=July 13, 2011}}</ref> It rapidly became an industry standard<ref name=Humboldt>{{cite web|title=Spectronic 20|url=http://www2.humboldt.edu/scimus/HSC.54-70/Descriptions/Spec20.htm|website=Robert A. Paselk Scientific Instrument Museum|publisher=Humboldt State University|accessdate=11 November 2015}}</ref> due to its low cost, durability and ease of use,<ref name=50years/> and has been referred to as an "iconic lab spectrophotometer".<ref name=Morris>{{cite journal|last1=Morris|first1=Rob|title=UNIT 2.1 Spectrophotometry|journal=Current Protocols Essential Laboratory Techniques|date=November 2, 2015|issue=Online|doi=10.1002/9780470089941.et0201s11}}</ref> Approximately 600,000 units were sold over its nearly 60 year production run. It has been the most widely used spectrophotometer worldwide.<ref name=Skoog/> Production was discontinued in 2011 when it was replaced by the Spectronic 200,<ref name=Ritter>{{cite journal|last1=Ritter|first1=Stephen K.|title=New And Notable At Pittcon: Pittcon Potpourri|journal=Chemical & Engineering News|date=April 4, 2011|volume=89|issue=14|pages=45–46|url=http://cen.acs.org/articles/89/i14/New-Notable-Pittcon-Pittcon-Potpourri.html|accessdate=11 November 2015}},</ref> but the Spectronic 20 is still in common use.<ref name="50years" /> It is sometimes referred to as the "Spec 20".<ref name="50years" />
==Design==
[[File:Figure 2 Colorimeter Cat no33-29-40 p4.tif | thumb|right | Schematic electrical diagram of the Bausch & Lomb Spectronic 20 Colorimeter]]
The Bausch & Lomb Spectronic 20 colorimeter uses a [[diffraction grating]] [[monochromator]] combined with a system for the detection, amplification, and measurement of light wavelengths in the 340 [[Nanometer|nm]] to 950 nm range.<ref name="Reference">{{cite book|title=Bausch & Lomb Spectronic 20 Colorimeter Cat No. 33-29-40, Reference manual|date=1962|publisher=Bausch & Lomb Incorporated|location=Rochester, New York}}</ref>{{rp|3}}
[[File:Figure 1 Colorimeter Cat no33-29-40 p3.tif | thumb|left | Schematic optical diagram of the Bausch & Lomb Spectronic 20 Colorimeter]]
As shown in the schematic optical diagram (see left), polychromatic light from a source in the system passes through lenses which are reflected and dispersed by the diffraction grating to restrict the range of light wavelengths. This restricted range of wavelengths is then passed through the sample to be measured. The intensity of the transmitted light is determined by a [[phototube]] [[detector]]. Mechanical movement of the diffraction grating by means of the cam attached to the wavelength control enables the user to select for various wavelengths. This is the "λ knob", wherein λ refers to wavelength of light used for the measurement.<ref name="Reference"/>{{rp|3–5}}
==Quantitative measurements== [[File:Beer's Law Plot.jpg|thumb|left |Beer-Lambert Relationship Plot]]
{{external media | width = 200px | align = right | headerimage= [[File:Figure 3 Colorimeter Cat no33-29-40 p5.tif |200px]] |video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QdufRwbkeKo “Introduction to Colorimetry“ (Spectronic 20)], David Frank | video2 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MOftc3f60OE “Absorbance Spectrophotometry Video 02, Function test for Spectronic 20+”], Robin Aiken |video3 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MkUGz6kEQMg “Lab Protocol - Spec 200 (Unit 2 Spectrophotometry)“], Mark Garcia}}
Many substances absorb light in the ultraviolet - visible light range. Absorption at any particular wavelength in the ultraviolet visible range is proportional to the concentration of the substances in the solution or other medium, in accord with the [[Beer-Lambert |Beer-Lambert relationship]]. In a practical sense, the Beer-Lambert relationship can be stated as:
''A'' = ε x ''l'' x ''c''
in which ''A'' is the absorbance measured by the instrument, ε is the molar absorption coefficient of the sample, ''l'' is the [[pathlength]] of the light beam through the sample, and c is the concentration of the substance in the solution or medium.<ref name="chemguide">{{cite web|title=The Beer-Lambert Law|url=http://www.chemguide.co.uk/analysis/uvvisible/beerlambert.html|website=chemguide.co.uk|publisher=Jim Clark|accessdate=7 April 2017}}</ref> The Spectronic 20 is thereby commonly used for [[Quantitative analysis (chemistry)|quantitative determination]] of the concentration of a substance of interest. The Spectronic 20 measures the absorbance of light at a pre-determined concentration, and the concentration is calculated from the Beer-Lambert relationship.<ref name="chemguide" />
The absorbance of the light is the [[base 10 logarithm]] of the [[ratio]] of the [[Transmittance]] of the pure solvent to the transmittance of the sample, and so the two absorbance and transmittance can be interconverted.<ref name="chemguide" /> Either transmittance or absorbance can therefore be plotted versus concentration using measurements from the Spectronic 20. Plotting a curve using percent transmittance of light yields an exponential curve. However, absorbance is linearly related to concentration, and so absorbance is often preferred for plotting a standard curve. This type of standard curve relates the concentration of the solution (on the x-axis) to measures of its absorbance (y-axis).<ref name="Austin"/>
To obtain such a curve, a series of dilutions of known concentration of a solution are prepared and readings are obtained for each of the dilutions (see plot at left).<ref name="Austin">{{cite web|title=BIOL 1406 PreLab 2.2 How can I use a spectrophotometer to determine the concentration of solutes in a solution?|url=http://www.austincc.edu/biocr/1406/labm/ex2/prelab_2_2.htm|website=Austin Community College|accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref> In this plot, the slope of the line is the product ε x ''l''. By measuring a series of standards and creating the standard curve, it is possible to quantify the amount or concentration of a substance within a sample by determining the absorbance on the Spec 20 and finding the corresponding concentration on the calibration curve. Alternatively, the logarithm of percent transmittance can be plotted versus concentration to create a standard curve using the same procedure.<ref name="Bates">{{cite web|title=Use of the Spec 20|url=http://abacus.bates.edu/~ganderso/biology/resources/spec20.html|website=Bates College|accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref>
The absorbance measured by the Spectronic 20 is the sum of the absorbance of each of the constituents of the solution. Therefore, the Spectronic 20 can be used to analyze more complex solutions. For example, if a sample solution has two [[Chromophore|light-absorbing compounds]] in it, then the user performs measurements at two different wavelengths and constructs standard curves for each compound. Then the concentration of each compound can be [[Algebra|calculated algebraically]].<ref name="Wiki">Wikipedia contributors. "[[Beer–Lambert law]]." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia, 15 Mar. 2017. Web. 8 Apr. 2017.</ref>
The Spectronic 20 can be used for [[Turbidimetry|turbidimetric measurements]]. In [[Microbiology|microbiological work]], the turbidity of a [[Microbiological culture|liquid culture of bacterial cells]] relates to the [[cell count]], and [[OD600]] measurements can be conducted for this purpose using the Spectronic 20.<ref name="OD600">{{cite web|last1=Baribeau|first1=Hélène|title=Formation and Decay of Disinfection By-Products in the Distribution System|url=http://www.waterrf.org/PublicReportLibrary/91115.pdf|website=waterrf.org|publisher=AWWA Research Foundation|accessdate=8 April 2017}}</ref> Likewise the turbidity of water suspensions of [[clays]] and other [[Light scattering by particles|particles]] of size suitable for [[light scattering]] can be quantitatively determined by means of a Spectronic 20.<ref name="CRC">{{cite book|last1=Kissa|first1=Erik|title=Dispersions: Characterization, Testing, and Measurement|date=1999|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=0824719948|pages=291–292}}</ref> In the past, the Spectronic 20 was used for [[Clinical chemistry|clinical diagnostic]] purposes.<ref name="Clinical">{{cite book|title=Clinical Methods Manual: Spectronic 20|date=1965|publisher=Bausch & Lomb, Inc.|location=New York}}</ref>
==Use== Before testing a sample, the Spectronic 20 is calibrated using a [[Blank (solution)|blank]] solution, which is the pure solvent that is used in the experimental sample. It is typically water or an [[organic solvent]]. In this calibration, the transmittance is set at 100% using the calibration knob of the instrument (the amplifier control knob in the figure at right). The instrument can also optionally be calibrated with a stock solution of a sample at a concentration known to have an absorbance of 2 or else vendor supplied standards, using the light absorption knob in the diagram shown at right.<ref name="Thermo2007" /> After calibration, the user places a 1/2 inch test tube or [[cuvette]] containing the [[Sample (material)|sample]] solution to be measured into the sample compartment.<ref name="Reference"/>{{rp|5}} Calibration is repeated each time the wavelength is changed. It or a standard reference sample is generally used to periodically check for [[Frequency drift|drift]]. To measure wavelengths above 650 [[Nanometres|nm]], the bottom of the instrument is opened, and a red [[filter (optics)|filter]] and a red-sensitive [[photocell]] is installed.<ref name="Reference"/>{{rp|7}}
The original design of the Spectronic 20 utilized an [[analog device|analog]] dial<ref name=Spectrophotometer>{{cite web|title=The Spectrophotometer|url=http://www2.ohlone.edu/people/jklent/labs/101a_labs/spectrophotometer.pdf}}</ref> for readout of transmission from 100%T to 1%T (top scale),<ref name=Murphy/> 0A - 2A (lower scale). Using the original instrument requires manual setting of the [[wavelength]]<ref name=Murphy/> and making readings from a moving-needle analog display.<ref name=Comparison/>
{{external media | width = 180px | align = right | headerimage= [[File:Standard curve.png |180px]] |video1 = [http://academics.wellesley.edu/Biology/Concepts/Html/standardcurve.html “The Standard Curve“ (Spec 20 Instructions)], [[Wellesley College]] }}
==Replacement== The Spectronic 20D (launched in 1985) and later the 20D+ replaced the analog dial with a red digital [[LED]] readout, offering greater [[Accuracy and precision|precision]] in the readout, if not greater [[accuracy]] in the actual reading. A side-by-side comparison of the features of the 20+ and 20D+ is available in the 2001 operating manual.<ref name=Comparison>{{cite web|title=SPECTRONIC ® 20 + SERIES Spectrophotometers Operator's Manual|url=http://www.cienytec.com/PDFS/Espec_SPEC20_OpMan_ing.pdf|website=ThermoSpectronic|date=2001}}</ref>
The Spectronic 20 was replaced by the Spectronic 200 in the Thermo Scientific spectrophotometer product line in 2011.<ref name=Ritter/> The Spectronic 200 utilizes an array detector and digital control of the measured wavelength, while retaining the characteristic λ knob of the Spec 20 for setting the wavelength. In addition to replicating the user modes of the Spec 20D+ (which it can emulate on a color LCD screen) the Spec 200 accommodates both test-tubes and square cuvettes without needing to install an adapter. Software modes described in the Spectronic 200's specifications include scanning, four wavelength simultaneous measurement, and [[quantitative analysis (chemistry)|quantitative analysis]] with up to four standards,<ref name=Spec200>{{cite web|title=Thermo Scientific SPECTRONIC 200 Visible Spectrophotometer|url=http://www.kobis.si/prodajni-program/molekulska-spektroskopija/SPECTRONIC%20200%20Visible%20Spectrophotometer_routine.pdf|website=Thermo Scientific|accessdate=11 November 2015}}</ref> in contrast to the SPEC 20D+ which offered only single point calibration.
==Product line history== Originally introduced by Bausch & Lomb in 1953, the product line was sold to Milton Roy in 1985. Milton Roy sold its instrument group to Life Sciences International, renamed Spectronic instruments, Inc. in 1995. Spectronics Instruments was purchased by Thermo Optek in 1997, renamed Spectronic-Unicam in 2001 and Thermo-Spectronic in 2002. In 2003 the product line was moved to [[Madison, WI]] and the brand renamed to [[Thermo Electron]].<ref name=Entities2015>{{cite web|title=Thermo Fisher Scientific Legal Entity Reference Guide US and Canada|url=https://corporate.thermofisher.com/content/dam/tf/Footer/Documents/2015%20Legal%20Entity%20Reference%20Guide.pdf|website=Thermo Fisher Scientific|accessdate=11 November 2015}}</ref>
With the merger of Thermo Electron and [[Fisher Scientific]] in 2006 the brand changed to [[Thermo Scientific]], and remained such until the end of the production run.<ref name=Thermo2006>{{cite web|title=Thermo Electron and Fisher Scientific to Combine in Industry-Transforming Transaction|url=http://ir.thermofisher.com/investors/news-and-events/news-releases/news-release-details/2006/Thermo-Electron-and-Fisher-Scientific-to-Combine-in-Industry-Transforming-Transaction/default.aspx|accessdate=11 November 2015|website=Thermo Fisher Scientific|date=May 8, 2006}}</ref> Spectronic 20 instruments found in labs today may bear any of the Bausch and Lomb, Milton Roy, Spectronic, Thermo Electron or Thermo Scientific brand names.<ref name=Entities2015/>
== Popular culture == The Spectronic 20 is apparently one of the few lab instruments to remain intact after the destruction of the laboratory in the movie ''[[Back to the Future]]''.<ref name=50years>{{cite web|title=Celebrating 50 years of spectrophotometry|url=http://www.laboratorytalk.com/analytical-instruments/spectroscopy/spectrophotometers/celebrating-50-years-of-spectrophotometry/54496.article|website=Thermo Fisher Scientific (Molecular Spectroscopy)|accessdate=10 December 2003}}</ref>

[[Rosaviakosmos]] | website = | COSPAR_ID = 1997-058C | SATCAT = | mission_duration = 1-2 months | spacecraft_bus = | manufacturer = | dry_mass = | launch_mass = {{convert|4|kg}} | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|5 October 1997, 15:08:57|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Soyuz-U]] | launch_site = [[Baikonur Cosmodrome|Baikonur]] [[Gagarin's Start|1/5]] | launch_contractor = | deployment_from = [[Mir]] | deployment_date = 3 November 1997, 04:05 UTC | last_contact = {{end-date|29 December 1997}} | decay_date = 21 May 1998 | orbit_epoch = 4 November 1997 | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Low Earth orbit|Low Earth]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|376|km|mi}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|382|km|mi}} | orbit_inclination = 51.6 degrees | orbit_period = | apsis = gee }} '''Sputnik 40''' ({{lang-ru|Спутник 40}}, {{lang-fr|Spoutnik 40}}), also known as '''Sputnik Jr''',{{cite web|url=http://www.n2yo.com/satellite/?s=24958|title=Sputnik Jr|publisher=N2YO|accessdate=15 August 2011}} '''PS-2''' and '''Radio Sputnik 17''' ('''RS-17'''),{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/sputnik-40.htm|title=Sputnik 40, 41, 99 (RS 17, 18, 19)|first=Gunter|last=Krebs|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=15 August 2011}} was a [[France|Franco-]][[Russia]]n [[amateur radio satellite]] which was launched in 1997 to commemorate the fortieth anniversary of the launch of [[Sputnik 1]], the world's first artificial satellite.{{cite web|url=http://www.amsat-france.org/spipamsat/article.php3?id_article=59|title=Spoutnik 40 (RS-17)|publisher=AMSAT-France|date=12 June 2006|accessdate=15 August 2011}} A {{convert|4|kg|adj=on}} one-third scale model of Sputnik 1,{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/psmodel.htm|title=PS Model|first=Mark|last=Wade|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=15 August 2011}} Sputnik 40 was deployed from the [[Mir]] [[space station]] on 3 November 1997.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/jsr/back/news.339|title=Issue 339|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|work=Jonathan's Space Report|date=5 November 1997|accessdate=15 August 2011}} Built by students, the spacecraft was constructed at the [[Polytechnic Laboratory of Nalchik]] in [[Kabardino-Balkaria]], whilst its transmitter was assembled by [[Jules Reydellet College]] in [[Réunion]] with technical support from [[AMSAT|AMSAT-France]]. ==Launch== Sputnik 40 was launched, along with a backup spacecraft and the [[X-Mir]] inspection satellite, aboard [[Progress M-36]] at 15:08 UTC on 5 October 1997.{{cite web|url=http://www.planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|work=Jonathan's Space Page|accessdate=15 August 2011}} A [[Soyuz-U]] carrier rocket placed the spacecraft into orbit, flying from [[Gagarin's Start|1/5]] at the [[Baikonur Cosmodrome]] in [[Kazakhstan]]: the same launch pad used by Sputnik 1. Progress M-36 docked to Mir on 8 October,{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/proressm.htm|title=Progress-M|first=Mark|last=Wade|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=15 August 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ilAZ94fo?url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/proressm.htm|archivedate=3 August 2009|df=dmy-all}} and the satellites were transferred to the space station. At 04:05 UTC on 3 November, during an [[extra-vehicular activity]], Sputnik 40 was deployed by cosmonauts [[Anatoly Solovyev]] and [[Pavel Vinogradov]].{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/mir.htm|title=Mir|first=Mark|last=Wade|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=15 August 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081223180808/http://www.astronautix.com/craft/mir.htm|archivedate=23 December 2008|df=dmy-all}} ==Orbit== On 4 November, the day after it was deployed, Sputnik 40 was in a [[low Earth orbit]] with a perigee of {{convert|376|km}}, an apogee of {{convert|382|km}}, an inclination of 51.6 degrees, and a period of 92.13 minutes.{{cite web|url=http://www.planet4589.org/space/log/satcat.txt|title=Satellite Catalog|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|work=Jonathan's Space Page|accessdate=15 August 2011}} The satellite was given the [[International Designator]] 1997-058C, and was [[Satellite Catalog Number|catalogued]] by the [[United States Space Command]] as 24958.{{cite web | title=SPACEWARN Activities, SPX-529| publisher=NASA | url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/spacewarn/spx529.html | date=1 December 1997 | accessdate=15 August 2011}} It ceased operations on 29 December 1997 when its batteries expired,{{cite web|title=Sputnik: First Artificial Satellite|url=http://www.batnet.com/mfwright/sputnik.html|date=30 August 1997 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061205021129/http://batnet.com/mfwright/sputnik.html |archivedate = 5 December 2006}}{{cite web | title= Tiny Beeping Model Tossed From Station | publisher=Space Today Online | url=http://www.spacetoday.org/Satellites/Hamsats/Hamsats1990s/Hamsats90sMiniSputnik.html | accessdate=15 August 2011}} and subsequently decayed from orbit on 21 May 1998. The backup satellite remained aboard Mir, and was destroyed when Mir was [[deorbit of Mir|deorbited]] on 23 March 2001. {{Clear}} ==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} * [[1997 in spaceflight]] {{Clear}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Radio Sputnik}} {{Orbital launches in 1997}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1997]] [[Category:Sputnik]]

'''VERDE (Visualizing Energy Resources Dynamically on the Earth)''' is a visualization and analysis capability of the [[United States Department of Energy]] (DOE). The system, developed and maintained by [[Oak Ridge National Laboratory]] (ORNL), provides wide-area situational understanding of the U.S. electric grid. Enabling grid monitoring, weather impacts prediction and analysis, VERDE supports preparedness and response to potentially large outage events. As a real-time geo-visualization capability, it characterizes the dynamic behavior of the grid over interconnects giving views into bulk transmission lines as well as county-level power distribution status. By correlating grid behaviors with cyber events, the platform also enables a method to link cyber-to-infrastructure dependencies.
VERDE integrates different data elements from other available on-line services, databases, and social media. The [[Tennessee Valley Authority]] (TVA) and other major utilities spanning multiple regions across the electric grid interconnection provide real-time status of their systems. Social media sources such as Twitter provide additional data-sources for visualization and analyses.
The VERDE software, which was developed by the Computational Sciences and Engineering Division (CSED) of ORNL, is used outside of the DOE for a number of related national security requirements.
== References ==
*Shankar, M., Stovall, J., Sorokine, A., Bhaduri, B., King, T. (Date 20–24 July 2008) Power and Energy Society General Meeting - Conversion and Delivery of Electrical Energy in the 21st Century, 2008 IEEE ''[http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpls/icp.jsp?arnumber=4596282 Visualizing Energy Resources Dynamically on Earth]
== Further reading ==
*Palmer, Katie. (26 September 2011) IEEE Spectrum. ''[http://spectrum.ieee.org/computing/software/grid-visualization-efforts-helped-heal-after-hurricane Multilayer mapping software sped grid restoration from Hurricane Irene damage]

{{Infobox book | name = Walkaway | image = Walkaway (a Cory Doctorow novel) book cover.jpg | caption = | author = [[Cory Doctorow]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[Dystopian|Dystopia]], [[Utopian|Utopia]], [[oligarchy]], [[surveillance]], [[Post-scarcity economy|post-scarcity]], [[alternative lifestyle]], [[war]] | genre = Adult Science Fiction | publisher = Head of Zeus, [[Tor Books]] | pub_date = {{Start date|2017|04|25}} | media_type = Book (Hardcover, Paperback and E-Book) | pages = 384 | isbn = 0-7653-9276-3 | congress= | oclc = | preceded_by = [[Homeland (Cory Doctorow novel)|Homeland]] | followed_by = | website = {{URL|craphound.com/category/walkaway}} }}
'''''Walkaway''''' is an adult [[science fiction]] novel by [[Cory Doctorow]], published by Head of Zeus and [[Tor Books]] in April 2017.
Set in our near-future, it is a story of walking away from "[[unemployment|non-work]]", and surveillance and control by a brutal, immensely rich [[oligarchy|oligarchical]] [[elite]]; love and romance; a [[Post-scarcity economy|post-scarcity]] [[gift economy]]; [[revolution]] and eventual war; and a means of finally ending death.<ref name="npr">{{cite web | author = Sheehan | first = Jason | title = In 'Walkaway,' A Blueprint For A New, Weird (But Better) World | work = [[NPR]] Online | publisher = [[NPR|National Public Radio]] | date = April 27, 2017 | url = https://www.npr.org/2017/04/27/523587179/in-walkaway-a-blueprint-for-a-new-weird-but-better-world | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170527115401/http://www.npr.org/2017/04/27/523587179/in-walkaway-a-blueprint-for-a-new-weird-but-better-world | archive-date = May 27, 2017 | accessdate = 2017-05-27}}</ref><ref name="the_verge">{{cite web | author = Robertson | first = Adi | title = Watch Edward Snowden and Cory Doctorow imagine our hopeful, dystopian future | work = [[The Verge]] | publisher = [[Vox Media]] | date = May 4, 2017 | url = https://www.theverge.com/2017/5/4/15547314/edward-snowden-cory-doctorow-nypl-talk-walkaway | archive-url = <!-- 403: Forbidden--> | archive-date = | accessdate = 2017-05-27}}</ref><ref name="ars_technica">{{cite web | author = Gallagher | first = Sean | title = Cory Doctorow's Walkaway: Hardware hackers face the climate apocalypse | work = [[Ars Technica]] | publisher = [[Condé Nast]] | date = April 25, 2017 | url = https://arstechnica.com/the-multiverse/2017/04/cory-doctorows-walkaway-hardware-hackers-face-the-climate-apocalypse/ | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170527115509/https://arstechnica.com/the-multiverse/2017/04/cory-doctorows-walkaway-hardware-hackers-face-the-climate-apocalypse/ | archive-date = May 27, 2017 | dead-url = no | accessdate = 2017-05-27}}</ref>
== Summary == In a world of [[Unemployment|non-work]], ruined by human-created [[climate change]] and [[pollution]], and where people are under [[surveillance]] and ruled over by a mega-rich [[elite]], Hubert, Etc, his friend Seth, and Natalie, decide that they have nothing to lose by turning their backs and walking away from the everyday world or "default reality".<ref name="ars_technica" /><ref name="WalkAway" />
With the advent of [[3D printing]] – and especially the ability to use these to fabricate even better fabricators – and with machines that can search for and reprocess waste or discarded materials, they no longer have need of Default for the basic essentials of life, such as food, clothing and shelter.<ref name="ars_technica" /><ref name="WalkAway" />
As more and more people choose to "walkaway", the ruling elite do not take these social changes sitting down. They use the military, police and [[mercenaries]] to attack and disrupt the walkaways' new [[Intentional communities|settlements]].<ref name="ars_technica" /><ref name="WalkAway" />
One thing that the elite are especially interested in is scientific research that the walkaways are carrying out which could finally put an end to death – and all this leads to revolution and eventual war.<ref name="ars_technica" /><ref name="WalkAway" />
== Main characters == * '''Hubert Espinoza''', better known as "Hubert, Etc" because of his nineteen middle names. Aged 27.<ref name="WalkAway">{{cite book | last = Doctorow | first = Cory | authorlink = Cory Doctorow | title = Walkaway | publisher = Head of Zeus | year = 2017 | location = | pages = | isbn = 0-7653-9276-3}}</ref> * '''Seth''': A friend of Hubert, Etc, who was "terrified of aging out of the beautiful children demographic and entering the world of non-work."<ref name="WalkAway" /> * '''Natalie Redwater''': Born into an elite family, she convinces Hubert, Etc, and Seth to walk away from the everyday world of "Default".<ref name="WalkAway" />
== Reception == Writing on ''[[NPR]]'' online, Jason Sheehan is of the opinion that Doctorow's writing is "super weird in the best possible way."<ref name="npr" />
The reviewer says that ''Walkaway'' is a remarkable "story of a utopia in progress, as messy as every new thing ever is, told in the form of people talking to each other, arguing with each other and working together to solve problems. It's all about the deep, disturbing, recognizable weirdness of the future that must come from the present we have already made for ourselves, trying to figure out what went wrong and what comes next."<ref name="npr" />
In ''[[The Verge]]'', Adi Robertson writes: "''Walkaway'' imagines a future shaped by the same problems and possibilities Doctorow's been playing with for years: the threat of ubiquitous surveillance and artificial scarcity, and the promise that almost any technology can be repurposed and turned against its creator".<ref name="the_verge" />
Robertson goes on to say that "one of Doctorow's core themes in ''Walkaway'' is subverting what he described as the popular 'man against man against nature' pulp plot."<ref name="the_verge" />
In ''[[Ars Technica]]'', Sean Gallagher writes that "the future is open source in this optimistic sci-fi disaster epic full of big ideas."<ref name="ars_technica" /> He and Doctorow see ''Walkaway'' as a prequel to the author's debut novel ''[[Down and Out in the Magic Kingdom]]''.<ref name="ars_technica" />
Gallagher concludes that ''Walkaway'' "shows us a world trying to make things right after having made all the wrong decisions about how to use technology. But Walkaway executes that move beautifully. And like all great performances, it's worth witnessing over and over again."<ref name="ars_technica" />
